case_name: Narandas Morardas Gaziwala and Lakshmi Chand Co. v. Murugesa Chettiar

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 177 and 178 of 1964 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 177 and 178 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 20, 1960, of the Madras High Court in Appeals Nos. 45 and 202 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 20, 1960, of the Madras High Court in Appeals Nos. 45 and 202 of 1957.

facts.text: Narandas Morardas Gaziwala and Lakshmi Chand Co. were two firms of partnership carrying on business in lace and silver thread at Surat in the State of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: Narandas Morardas Gaziwala and Lakshmi Chand Co. were two firms of partnership carrying on business in lace and silver thread at Surat in the State of Bombay.

facts.text: Krishna and Company at Kumbakonam acted as agents for the Surat firms for selling goods in Tanjore, Tiruchirapalli and Madurai districts on commission basis.

anchor.surface_text: They had dealings with another firm at Kumbakonam-Krishna and Company-who acted as their agents for selling their goods in the three districts of Tanjore, Tiruchirapalli and Mathurai in the State of Madras on companymission basis.

facts.text: Krishna Co. acted as commission agents from 1944 till 1951.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that Krishna Co. was acting as companymission agents on behalf of the two firms at Surat from 1944 till 1951 when the partnership of Krishna Co. became dissolved by mutual agreement between the partners.

facts.text: Partnership of Krishna Co. dissolved by mutual agreement in 1951; Murugesa Chettiar took over all assets and liabilities; Gopal Chettiar retired.

anchor.surface_text: when the partnership of Krishna Co. became dissolved by mutual agreement between the partners. Murugesa Chettiar, one of the partners of ,Krishna Co. took over all the assets and liabilities of the firm on dissolution and the other partner Gopal Chettiar retired from the firm.

facts.text: Krishna Co. became indebted to Surat Firm in 1951.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of the dealings of the two firms at Surat  here. inafter to be referred to as the Surat Firm  with Krishna Co., the latter became indebted in 1951.

facts.text: On April 1, 1951, Murugesa Chettiar executed a promissory note in favour of Narandas Morardas Gaziwala for Rs. 7,500/- due from Krishna Co.

anchor.surface_text: On April 1, 1951 Murugesa Chettiar  hereinafter referred to as the plaintiff  executed a pro. missory numbere in favour of Narandas Morardas Gaziwala for a sum of Rs. 7.500/- the amount ascertained as due and payable by Krishna Co.

facts.text: Plaintiff claims Surat Firm constituted him as sole agent for 5 years from April 1, 1951 for three districts, commission Rs. 2/- per mark.

anchor.surface_text: It is the case of the plaintiff that on April 1, 1951 the Surat firm companystituted Murugesa Chettiar as the sole agent for selling their goods bearing the trade mark Napoleon Vivekanada and other marks for the three districts for a period of 5 years from April 1, 1951 agreeing to pay companymission at a flat rate of Rs. 2/- per mark for all sales effected in those territories either on orders booked, by him or number.

facts.text: Plaintiff claims Surat Firm circumvented sole agency by private sales through others or direct to customers.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the plaintiff was that the Surat firm circumvented the terms of this companytract of sole agency and privately effected sales through others or direct to customers in those territories.

facts.text: Surat Firm agreed to adjust indebtedness under promissory note towards commissions earned by plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs companytention further was that the Surat fim as part of this agreement of sole agency agreed to have its indebtedness under the promissory numbere adjusted towards the companymission that may be earned by him.

facts.text: Plaintiff instituted O.S. No. 87 of 1954 in District Munsif's Court, Kancheepuram for rendition of accounts from April 1, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff therefore instituted O.S. No. 87 of 1954 in the District Munsifs Court, Kancheepuram praying for rendition of accounts from April 1, 1951 till the date of the suit in order to ascertain the amount due and payable to him.

facts.text: Surat Firm instituted O.S. No. 21 of 1954 in Court of Subordinate Judge, Chingleput to recover Rs. 7,500 under promissory note.

anchor.surface_text: The Surat LS5SCI--5 firm in its turn instituted O.S. number 21 of 1954 in the companyrt of Subordinate Judge, Chingleput against the plaintiff seeking to recover the amount due under the promissory numbere. viz., a sum of Rs. 7.500/

facts.text: O.S. 87/1954 transferred to Subordinate Judge, Chingleput as O.S. 35/1955; both suits tried together by consent.

anchor.surface_text: By an order of the District Court, Chingleput O.S. number 87 of 1954 on the file of District Munsif, Kancheepuram was transferred to the file of the Subordinate Judge, Chingleput and taken on his file as O.S. number 35 of 1955. Both the suits were tried together by company- sent of parties.

facts.text: On December 12, 1956, Subordinate Judge granted preliminary decree for accounts in O.S. 35/1955, holding sole agency for 5 years.

anchor.surface_text: On December 12, 1956 the Subordinate Judge held that the plaintiff was companystituted as the sole agent on companymission basis for the three territories, Tanjore, Tiruchirappalli and Madurai for a period of 5 years as pleaded and proved by him and the Surat firm was liable to render an account of their sales in those territories from April 1, 1951 and accordingly granted a preliminary decree for rendition of accounts.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge granted decree in O.S. 21/1954 for promissory note amount but to be adjusted against commissions.

anchor.surface_text: In O.S. number 21 of 1954 the Subordinate Judge granted a decree for the amount companyered by the promissory numbere but directed that the decretal amount should be adjusted out of the companymission that may be found due and payable on taking of accounts in O.S. number 35 of 1955.

facts.text: Surat Firm appealed: A.S. 45/1957 against O.S. 21/1954; appeal against O.S. 35/1955 transferred to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Surat firm preferred an appeal against the decree in O.S. number 21 of 1954A.S. number 45 of 1957. They also preferred an appeal against, the decree in O.S. 35 of 1955 to the District Court of Chingleput and that appeal was transferred to the High Court and heard along with A.S. number 45 of 1957.

facts.text: Madras High Court by judgment dated September 20, 1961 dismissed both appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, by its judgment dated September 20, 1961, dismissed both the appeals.

facts.text: High Court found transactions for commission peculiarly within knowledge of Surat Firm; prima facie evidence of direct sales.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the High Court has found that the transactions in respect of which the plaintiff is entitled to companymission are peculiarly within the knowledge of the principal alone, viz., of the Surat firm. There is also prima facie evidence adduced on behalf of the plaintiff in this case in support of his allegation that the Surat firm had made direct sales to customers in companytravention of the companytract of sole agency granted to the plaintiff.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds plaintiff entitled to sue for accounts in special circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the  opinion that, in the special circumstances of this case, the plaintiff is entitled to sue the Surat firm for accounts for the material period.

facts.text: High Court found collateral oral agreement that promissory note obligation not enforceable for 5 years unless amount due after accounting.

anchor.surface_text: The finding of the High Court is that there was a companylateral oral agreement that the obligation under the promissory numbere will number be enforced for 5 years and unless the amount was due after accounting for the period of the companymission agency.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds oral agreement was condition precedent to enforceability of promissory note, admissible under proviso 3 to S.92 Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the agreement was number related to the mode of discharge of the obligation under the promissory numbere but that it Was a companydition precedent to the enforceability of the promissory numbere and it is open to the plaintiff to adduce evidence of oral agreement under the 3rd proviso to S. 92 of the Evidence Act.

facts.text: Two partners of Krishna Co.: Murugesa Chettiar and Gopal Chettiar (wife's sister's husband).

anchor.surface_text: The two partners of Krishna Co. were Murugesa Chettiar and his wifes sisters husband Gopal Chettiar.

facts.text: Evidence of direct sales: Exs. A-26 and A-28, complaints to Surat firm about sales to Mr. M.K. Iyengar; no replies.

A-26 and A-28-which are companyplaints made by the plaintiff to the Surat firm with regard to direct sales made to Mr. M. K. lyengar,The high companyrt has also observed that to numbere of the letters or tele grams from the plaintiff the Surat firm or their accredited representative Ratilal cared to send any reply.

facts.text: Plaintiff is Murugesa Chettiar.

issues.text: The first question presented for determination in these appeals is whether the plaintiff is entitled to sue for accounts, he being the agent and the defendant-Surat firm being the principal.

anchor.surface_text: The first question presented for determination in these appeals is whether the plaintiff is entitled to sue for accounts, he being the agent and the defendant-Surat firm being the principal.

issues.text: the next question involved in this case viz. whether the plaintiff is entitled to set up a parole agreement to prove the condition precedent as to the enforceability of the promissory note.

anchor.surface_text: We proceed to consider the next question involved in this case viz. whether the plaintiff is entitled to set up a parole agreement to prove the condition precedent as to the enforceability of the promissory note.

holdings.text: The Indian Contract Act is not exhaustive and the right of the agent to sue the principal for accounts is an equitable right arising under special circumstances and is not a statutory right.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the statute is number exhaustive and the rightof the agent to sue the principal for accounts is an equitable rightarising under special circumstances and is number a statutory right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 213 provides only for principal's statutory right against agent; agent's right is equitable, recognized in English law (Bowstead, Story, cases like Shepard v. Brown, Blyth v. Whiffin) and Indian cases (Madras, Lahore, Nagpur High Courts).

holdings.text: In the special circumstances of this case, the plaintiff is entitled to sue the Surat firm for accounts for the material period.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that, in the special circumstances of this case, the plaintiff is entitled to sue the Surat firm for accounts for the material period.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court finding that transactions peculiarly within Surat Firm's knowledge; prima facie evidence of direct sales contravening sole agency (Exs. A-26, A-28 complaints to Surat Firm about sales to M.K. Iyengar, no replies).

holdings.text: The agreement was not related to the mode of discharge of the obligation under the promissory note but it was a condition precedent to the enforceability of the promissory note and it is open to the plaintiff to adduce evidence of oral agreement under the 3rd proviso to S. 92 of the Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the agreement was number related to the mode of discharge of the obligation under the promissory numbere but that it Was a companydition precedent to the enforceability of the promissory numbere and it is open to the plaintiff to adduce evidence of oral agreement under the 3rd proviso to S. 92 of the Evidence Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court finding of collateral oral agreement suspending enforcement for 5 years unless amount due post-accounting; distinguishes from defeasance altering legal effect.

holdings.text: Such an oral agreement constitutes a condition precedent to the attaching of the obligation and is within the terms of Proviso 3 of s. 92 of the Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: Such an oral agreement companystitutes a companydition precedent to the attaching of the obligation and is within the terms of Proviso 3 of s. 92 of the Evidence Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Judicial Committee in Rowland Ady v. Administrator-General of Burma: distinguishes collateral agreement altering effect from one suspending operation until condition fulfilled; applies to promissory note payable on demand.

holdings.text: The oral agreement found to have been proved by the High Court constituted a condition precedent to the attaching of the obligation under the promissory note and falls within the terms of the 3rd proviso to s. 92 of the Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: In that present case also we are of opinion that the oral agreement found to have been proved by the High Court companystituted a companydition precedent to the attaching of the obligation under the promissory numbere and falls within the terms of the 3rd proviso to s. 92 of the evidence Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms High Court factual finding on existence of oral agreement; applies Proviso 3 as per Rowland Ady and distinguishes Ramjibun Serowgy.
